liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is posting modest early gains, although Australia's two biggest miners have fallen further into the red on fears about Chinese commodity demand as one of the nation's largest developers teeters on the brink of collapse. This is the latest on the Country Garden situation from Reuters : China's largest private real estate developer Country Garden is seeking to delay payment on a private onshore bond for the first time, the latest sign of a stifling cash crunch in the property sector, piling pressure on Beijing to step in. Adding to worries about contagion risk, a major Chinese trust company that traditionally had sizable exposure to real estate, Zhongrong International Trust Co, has missed its repayment obligations on some investment products. Analysts warned that a rise in default by trust companies, also known as shadow banks, which have strong ties to the domestic property sector, will further weigh on the world's second-largest economy. Those fears have seen BHP and Rio Tinto fall around 0.5% in early trade, after steeper drops yesterday. Fortescue Metals is holding up, however, rising 1.1%. Industrials, energy and mining were among the sectors slightly in the red on the ASX 200 today, but big gains in healthcare and solid rises for tech, real estate and financials more than offset those losses. There are 109 companies on the up, compared to only 72 of the top 200 on the slide. The ASX 200 is up 0.3% to 7,300 points in the first 20 minutes of trade. The Aussie dollar has also stabilised, sitting at 64.89 US cents .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX rebounds from yesterday's drop, though Chinese developer fears linger

children.content: The
Australian share market is posting modest early gains
, although Australia's two biggest miners have fallen further into the red on fears about Chinese commodity demand as one of the nation's largest developers teeters on the brink of collapse.
This is the latest on the
Country Garden
situation from
Reuters

China's largest private real estate developer Country Garden is seeking to delay payment on a private onshore bond for the first time, the latest sign of a stifling cash crunch in the property sector, piling pressure on Beijing to step in.

Adding to worries about contagion risk, a major Chinese trust company that traditionally had sizable exposure to real estate, Zhongrong International Trust Co, has missed its repayment obligations on some investment products.

Analysts warned that a rise in default by trust companies, also known as shadow banks, which have strong ties to the domestic property sector, will further weigh on the world's second-largest economy.
Those fears have seen
BHP and Rio Tinto fall around 0.5%
in early trade, after steeper drops yesterday.
Fortescue Metals
is holding up, however,
rising 1.1%
Industrials, energy and mining
were among the sectors slightly
in the red
on the ASX 200 today, but
big gains in healthcare and solid rises for tech, real estate and financials
more than offset those losses.
There are 109 companies on the up, compared to only 72 of the top 200 on the slide.
The
ASX 200 is up 0.3% to 7,300 points
in the first 20 minutes of trade.
The
Aussie dollar
has also stabilised, sitting at
64.89 US cents

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Having just discussed Australia's wine glut, we have results from the nation's biggest player, Treasury Wine Estates (TWE). It has reported a 3.3% decline in net profit after tax to $254.5 million on a 2.2% fall in sales revenue. However, its earnings before tax, interest and material one-offs climbed 11.4% to $583.5 million, with underlying net profit (excluding those one-offs) rising 16.6% to $376.1 million. The company says its strategy of "premiumisation" is working to improve profit margins on the wine it is selling, with its margin jumping 2.9 percentage points to 24.1%. It is targeting a margin of around 25%. TWE said demand for its luxury and premium wines remains solid, especially its flagship Penfolds brand, which saw both sales and profits rise more than 14%. The company says it expects demand for its luxury wines to continue being strong, while premium wine demand is expected to remain "consistent". However, "commercial" wine demand is expected to "remain challenged" with TWE predicting further volume decreases for the mass market segment. The company has declared a final dividend of 17 cents per share, which leaves the full-year payout for shareholders at 35 cents per share.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasury Wine Estates profits falls, but Penfolds softens the blow

children.content: Having just discussed Australia's wine glut, we have results from the nation's biggest player,
Treasury Wine Estates (TWE)
It has reported
a 3.3% decline in net profit after tax to $254.5 million on a 2.2% fall in sales revenue
However, its earnings before tax, interest and material one-offs climbed 11.4% to $583.5 million, with
underlying net profit (excluding those one-offs) rising 16.6% to $376.1 million
The company says its strategy of "premiumisation" is working to improve profit margins on the wine it is selling, with its
margin jumping 2.9 percentage points to 24.1%
. It is targeting a margin of around 25%.
TWE said demand for its luxury and premium wines remains solid, especially its flagship
Penfolds brand, which saw both sales and profits rise more than 14%
The company says it expects demand for its luxury wines to continue being strong, while premium wine demand is expected to remain "consistent".
However, "commercial" wine demand is expected to "remain challenged" with TWE predicting further volume decreases for the mass market segment.
The company has declared
a final dividend of 17 cents per share
, which leaves the full-year payout for shareholders at 35 cents per share.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, welcome to the ABC Markets Blog. Wall Street closed higher, boosted by technology stocks as chipmaker Nvidia jumped on optimism about AI. The Nasdaq put on 1 per cent and the S & P500 rose 0.6 per cent. The Australian dollar fell to 64.55 US cents overnight because of fears China's largest private property developer Country Garden could default. Yesterday, the Australian share market hit a four-week low on worries about the problems in China's property industry. Companies reporting profit results today include vaccine maker CSL, jobs website Seek and Treasury Wine Estates. And the latest data on wages will be out, as well as the minutes from the Reserve Bank's board meeting earlier this month. Join us for all today's market's news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US stocks rise, Australian dollar slumps

children.content: Good morning, welcome to the ABC Markets Blog.
Wall Street closed higher, boosted by technology stocks as chipmaker Nvidia jumped on optimism about AI.
The Nasdaq put on 1 per cent and the S
P500 rose 0.6 per cent.
The Australian dollar fell to 64.55 US cents overnight because of fears China's largest private property developer Country Garden could default.
Yesterday, the Australian share market hit a four-week low on worries about the problems in China's property industry.
Companies reporting profit results today include vaccine maker CSL, jobs website Seek and Treasury Wine Estates.
And the latest data on wages will be out, as well as the minutes from the Reserve Bank's board meeting earlier this month.
Join us for all today's market's news.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC US media outlets including CNN and MSNBC are reporting the grand jury has delivered 10 indictments, which could mean 10 or more people have been charged. The court clerk told reporters that it could be up to three hours before the details of the indictments are made public. Donald Trump already faces federal charges over his alleged efforts to have Joe Biden's 2020 election win overturned. He pleaded not guilty to those charges in a Washington court earlier this month. He’s also pleaded not guilty to offences relating to the handling of classified documents in Florida, and allegedly falsified business records in New York.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US media say Georgia's grand jury has delivered 10 indictments in Trump election probe

children.content: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC
US media outlets including CNN and MSNBC are reporting the grand jury has delivered 10 indictments, which could mean 10 or more people have been charged.
The court clerk told reporters that it could be up to three hours before the details of the indictments are made public.
Donald Trump already faces federal charges over his alleged efforts to have Joe Biden's 2020 election win overturned.
He pleaded not guilty to those charges in a Washington court earlier this month.
He’s also pleaded not guilty to offences relating to the handling of
classified documents
in Florida, and
allegedly falsified business records
in New York.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Tigers icon is expected to announce his retirement this morning ending a 17-year career. He leaves the team just shy of 350 games and 786 goals kicked, making him one of the greatest goal kickers for the club. The 34-year-old was part of Richmond's premiership-winning era between 2017 and 2021 and was named all-Australian three times. Riewoldt joins former captain Trent Cotchin in announcing 2023 will be their final season. Riewoldt is expcted to make the official announcement at a press conference on Tuesday afternoon. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Richmond legend Jack Riewoldt expected to announce retirement from AFL

featuredLink.title: Richmond great Jack Riewoldt set to call it a day after three flags, 17 seasons

props.alt: Jack Riewoldt in black and yellow tigers uniform.

children.content: (AAP: Joel Carrett)
The Tigers icon is expected to announce his retirement this morning ending a 17-year career.
He leaves the team just shy of 350 games and
786 goals kicked, making him one of the greatest goal kickers for the club.
The 34-year-old was part of Richmond's premiership-winning era between 2017 and 2021 and was named all-Australian three times.
Riewoldt
joins former captain Trent Cotchin
in announcing 2023 will be their final season.
Riewoldt is expcted to make the official announcement at a press conference on Tuesday afternoon.
You can read more here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Michael Oher, the former NFL player known for being the inspiration for the 2009 movie The Blind Side starring Sandra Bullock, is suing Sean and Leigh Anne Tuohy for allegedly lying to him by having him sign papers making them his conservators rather than his adoptive parents nearly two decades ago. In his petition, Oher asks for the conservatorship to be terminated along with asking for a full accounting of the money earned off the use of his name and story. He also asks to be paid what he is due, along with interest. He accuses the Tuohys of enriching themselves at his expense by continuing to "falsely and publicly" represent themselves as his adoptive parents "to the date of the filing of this petition". "Oher discovered this lie to his chagrin and embarrassment in February of 2023, when he learned that the Conservatorship, to which he consented on the basis that doing so would make him a member of the Tuohy family, in fact provided him no familial relationship with the Tuohys," according to the petition. Oher, who has never been a fan of the movie about his life, also asks in the petition that the Tuohys be sanctioned and required to pay both compensatory and punitive damages determined by the court. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The man who inspired the movie The Blind Side is suing to end his conservatorship

featuredLink.title: The man behind the Blind Side movie story sues parents for not really adopting him

props.alt: A photo of a black man in an NFL jersey, next to a photo of a black man sitting on a street curb next to a white woman

children.content: (AP: Nick Wass, Supplied: Warner Brothers)
Michael Oher, the former NFL player known for being the inspiration for the 2009 movie The Blind Side starring Sandra Bullock, is
suing Sean and Leigh Anne Tuohy for allegedly lying to him by having him sign papers making them his conservators rather than his adoptive parents nearly two decades ago
In his petition, Oher asks for the conservatorship to be terminated along with asking for a full accounting of the money earned off the use of his name and story.
He also asks to be paid what he is due, along with interest.
He accuses the Tuohys of enriching themselves at his expense by continuing to "falsely and publicly" represent themselves as his adoptive parents "to the date of the filing of this petition".

"Oher discovered this lie to his chagrin and embarrassment in February of 2023, when he learned that the Conservatorship, to which he consented on the basis that doing so would make him a member of the Tuohy family, in fact provided him no familial relationship with the Tuohys," according to the petition.
Oher, who has never been a fan of the movie about his life, also asks in the petition that the Tuohys be sanctioned and required to pay both compensatory and punitive damages determined by the court.
You can read more here:
